I try to go to Crystal Cove once a year and spend a week. There is something so relaxing and healing about walking the trails above the open and then walking or running the beach. One the the few preserved areas where you can see what the coast used to look like before all of the water heavy decorative plants were brought in. It is a beautiful desert oasis and the history of cabins built there is fascinating. Please take the time to read the wonderful information cards on the "main" cabins and go through the Visitor Center area. Loved the little gift shop, too and don't miss the Beachcomber Mexican restaurant! The Beignets are mouthwatering treats!

We did the Moderate Loop Trail (and added in a little bit to make it longer) but it was hilly, beautiful and a fun time. Crystal Cove State Park is several parks in one. Located along PCH south of Newport Beach and Costa Mesa along the shore you'll run into the park's many entrances. The four parking lots are in chaparral with numerous walkways and hiking paths among the cacti, sage and tumbleweeds. Most of the paths head towards various sections of the beach cliffs, with several picturesque spots along the way. If you make your way down to the beach like we did, there's a section of nice swimming and surfing beach area, a tide pool section to climb and search for wildlife in the pools, a popular underwater diving spot and if you walk a little further, a small little beach front ghost town.

Somewhere between 20-30 houses along the beach and halfway down the cliffs have been condemned and are now part of the state park. Each looks to be derelict and in various states of decay and are protected from humans by chain link fence. Only the top row of homes at the tops of the cliffs are preserved and appear to be rent-able through the park. The architecture was clearly done for most of the homes in the late 1940's to 1960's era surf town.

There are a few shops and stores, a visitors center, bathrooms, two restaurants and a bar on site. We managed to grab some margaritas and cold water from the bar as we rested, preparing for the return hike up the sandstone cliffs to our car later that afternoon.

It's a really cool place to check out. I don't recommend the sandy trails for strollers but there is easier access to the cove via steps. Families with older children five and up won't have any problems. It's a real hidden gem that shows you what life was like for a beach boys beach town 70 years ago.

Sun, sand and surf and a couple of great visits

Our first visit, during the late October heat wave, saw us park up behind the beach. We walked down the long winding path to the sand below, admiring the surf as we went.
The whole beach was clean, tidy and inviting from the start.
Once on the sand, we swam and enjoyed the surf, despite its powerful undertow. The beach was quiet, not deserted but very quiet and very relaxing and enjoyable in the 95F / 38C sun. Lots of seabirds also enjoyed the beach, adding interest. Toward the southern end of the beach, low-lying rocks and rock pools provide an opportunity for more advanced beachcombing, with wildlife varying from tiny fish to sea anenomes land more beside. But the rocks can be deceptively slippery, particularly when wet.
Overall, a couple of great afternoons that we'll remember for many years.
Go for it and find your own memories. And the little beachside bar and restaurant may help you do that.

Crystal Cove/El Moro campground is fantastic! The views are awesome. The campground is clean and the hiking is perfect.
Each campsite is very big with space in front of your rig (or whatever) for chairs and blankets. The sites are tiered to allow a coastal view for all campers. RVs are kept to a few top loops of the campground and soft camping with tents and pop ups are on their own lower loops. Trails around the campground are well taken care of and the area is clean (including the bathrooms)! Hiking is conveniently located behind the campground in the canyon and the trails are well maintained. The trails are challenging but not ridiculous, offering nice views and a deceptively peaceful getaway even though civilization is very close. Mountain biking is allowed, but no dogs on trails. I know there is wildlife, but I’ve only seen birds and a mouse on the trail. In hot summer I can imagine the snakes as stated on the signage near the trails.
Access to the beach is also effortless - just a short walk down to the day use parking lot and a cross through the tunnel. A Beautiful beach awaits. So quiet during the week. Campgrounds have to be reserved far in advance.
If you can get a reservation, I recommend this campground. It’s worth the price (which is a bit expensive).

Crystal Cove State Park is a gorgeous must-see in Laguna Beach. Located minutes down the highway from Newport Beach, it's a respite from crowds. The shore is gorgeous and rocky with excellent surf. We chose Crystal Cove State Park for a beach day, showing up early in the morning at low tide, and clambered down the cliff to the tidal pools, which were full of colorful crabs and minnows. At a larger pool, some lads had captured two sea slugs, and spotted an octopus just as it camouflaged, as well as a baby tiger shark. An interesting morning for sure. After lunch we went further down the cove to a beach area that was not quite as rocky. The surf seemed to be rather high so we checked with a life guard to see what her recommendation was for people who would like to do some body surfing but who were not familiar with ocean swimming. Apparently there had been a hurricane off shore, and the swells were bigger than usual, so she recommended that we go to the pool for the remainder of the week we were in California. If we did go in not to go deeper than thigh-deep. So we sat down to watch the ocean for a few hours. It was bringing in chunks of concrete and asphalt that were bigger than my head and a cement block one time. Glad I did not venture into that. We waded knee deep and got wet feeling the sea suck the sand out from beneath our feet. But the day was lovely, and the sea air refreshing. And with all things having to do with nature, one has to have respect for forces that are more powerful than we are. All in all, it was a great day.

We are in Orange County several times a year to visit our son and we always make time to visit Crystal Cove State Park. It is the kind of place that I could visit daily for the rest of my life and never grow tired of. The park is actually quite large and encompasses bluffs overlooking the Pacific as well as a string of beautiful beaches that run from Corona del Mar/Newport area up to and connecting with the beaches at Laguna.

There are multiple entrances to the park and each one of them leads to a beautiful bluff area covered with wildflowers and California sage brush and a trail or trails down to the beach. There are paved parking, facilities and hiking/running trails up top and, depending on the entrance you select, either a stairway or steep walkway down to the beach.The bluffs and beaches are wild and natural, not groomed or landscaped. There are some nice rock outcroppings on the beach and tide pools as well--be sure to check a tide table if you want to explore the tide pools as they are submerged most of the day. Make sure you take note of where you park and which walkway you take down to the beach so you can easily find your way back. There are no bathrooms or facilities down at the beach level unless you are up near the Beach Comber Restaurant so be sure to plan ahead. Bring what you need and be prepared to pack it in and out.

Crystal Cove Cottages is a hidden gem. They are renovated cottages built in the 1940s. You have to make reservations for a cottage six months ahead on the first of the month. I went on in April 1st and got a reservation at 8:08 and all of the cottages were booked for October by 8:15. We booked #40. A small cozy cottage that is literally on the beach. It is small for two and a child. But it has a large deck that is about 40 ft from the ocean. Absolutely great. We just chilled for two days and nights. Walked on the beach, ate, sleep, did nothing. So cool. If you're looking for a Hyatt Regency don't stay here. It's a step back in time. No TV, no phone, only a microwave but wifi and cell. So relaxing. There is the Beachcomber restaurant on site a very short walk from #40. The staff was outstanding and very friendly. I highly recommend it. Dynamite.

Lovely Beach & Cottages but surrounding area not the same

This is a beautiful spot, but having lived in SoCal for about 16 years having moved there in the mid 90's it is sad to see how much this area has changed. I am glad they are preserving the Crystal Cove Cottages rather than having big developers scale the hill with mansions like the rest of the area. There is good parking across PCH but it's not what it used to be. People no longer drive the coast leisurely to enjoy the pacific ocean but portions of PCH is now 3 lanes each direction, I came home calling it the new PCH speedway. Development is not always a good thing and the hills are littered with expansive homes, condos and resorts which enjoy the view but have literally ruined the landscape for those of us that remember what we loved about the Southern CA coast line along this stretch. Thankfully the cottages are there and maintain what is left of the SoCal beach culture. It is rumored the last little cottage on the beach was used for a scene with Bette Midler and Barbara Hershey in the movie Beaches. So be careful getting to the beach. The beach itself is beautiful and fortunately the crashing waves and portions of hills will diffuse the sound of cars speeding down PCH. So great beach, great views, great place to relax but on my way there I felt I was going to be run off the road by speeding traffic.
